children.value: Write more robust and understandable programs.
You're reading the documentation. Other exits are:
Play around with an example that uses React in
You can install Statebot into your

I've included Statebot in this page. Open the developer-console to
follow along with the examples below:

tags.title: memberof
tags.description: statebot

tags.title: example
tags.description:
var machine = Statebot('lemming', {
  chart: `
    walking -> (digging | building | falling) ->
      walking

    falling -> splatting
    walking -> exiting
  `
})

children.value: Assert that a certain route can be followed by a

This merely tests that a certain path can be taken through a
state-machine. It doesn't assert that the states are moved-through
while the machine is working, as with

tags.title: memberof
tags.description: statebot

tags.title: param
tags.description: The machine to test the route on.
tags.name: machine

tags.title: param
tags.description:
The route to test as an arrow-delimited string:

 `
 "idle -> pending -> success -> done"
 `
tags.name: route

tags.title: example

children.value: The machine to test the route on.
The route to test as an arrow-delimited string:

only checks
that a particular route can be followed,

will hook-into
a machine and wait for it to trace the specified path within a
timeout period.

tags.title: memberof
tags.description: statebot

tags.title: param
tags.description: The machine to run the assertion on.
tags.name: machine

tags.title: param
tags.description:
The expected route as an arrow-delimited string:

 `
 "idle -> pending -> success -> done"
 `
tags.name: expectedRoute

tags.title: example
tags.description:
var machine = Statebot(...)

assertRoute(
  machine, 'prepare -> debounce -> sending -> done -> idle',
  {
    description: 'Email sent with no issues',
    fromState: 'idle',
    timeoutInMs: 1000 * 20,
    permittedDeviations: 0,
    logLevel: 3
  }
)
.then(() => console.log('Assertion passed!'))
.catch(err => console.error(`Whoops: ${err}`))

machine.enter('idle')

examples.description:
var machine = Statebot(...)

assertRoute(
  machine, 'prepare -> debounce -> sending -> done -> idle',
  {
    description: 'Email sent with no issues',
    fromState: 'idle',
    timeoutInMs: 1000 * 20,
    permittedDeviations: 0,
    logLevel: 3
  }
)
.then(() => console.log('Assertion passed!'))
.catch(err => console.error(`Whoops: ${err}`))

machine.enter('idle')

tags.description: The state-chart.

tags.title: property
tags.description:
The state in which to start. If unspecified, the first state in the
 chart will be used.
tags.name: startIn

tags.title: property
tags.description:
How noisy the logging is, from 1 to 3:
 ```
 1) console.warn
 2) console.warn/log/table
 3) console.warn/log/table/info
 ```
 `3` is the default. Argument type-errors will always `throw`.
tags.name: logLevel

tags.title: property
tags.description:
Limit how much history the state-machine keeps. Accessed via
 {@link #statebotfsmhistory|statebotFsm#history()}.
tags.name: historyLimit

tags.title: property
tags.description:
If you wish to have your Statebots listen to events coming from
 a shared EventEmitter, you can pass it in here. The `emit()`/`onEvent()`/
 `performTransitions()` methods will use it.

 It should have the same signature as {@link https://nodejs.org/api/events.html#events_class_eventemitter|EventEmitter}.

 - Since Statebot 2.5.0 {@link https://npmjs.com/mitt|mitt} is also compatible.
 - Since Statebot 2.6.0 {@link https://npmjs.com/mitt|mitt} is used internally.
tags.name: events

If you wish to have your Statebots listen to events coming from

It should have the same signature as

A description of all the states in a machine, plus all of the
permitted transitions between them.
It's the only operator needed to build any chart:

var promiseLikeChart = `
  pending -> resolved
  pending -> rejected
  resolved -> done
  rejected -> done
`
can help us remove some redundancy from the above example:

var promiseLikeChart = `
  pending -> resolved | rejected
  resolved | rejected -> done
`
We can streamline this even further:
Again, this is exactly equivalent to the previous two examples.
Notice in this one that we have parentheses

. They are actually completely ignored by the parser, and
you can use them as you please to help make your charts more readable.
A chart works exactly the same without them:

var promiseLikeChart = `
  pending -> resolved | rejected -> done
`
Charts can also be split across multiple-lines:

var promiseLikeChart = `
  pending ->
  resolved |
  rejected ->
  done
`
Notice that all white-space is ignored on either side of the
// Comments of this kind are allowed, too:

var promiseLikeChart = `
  pending -> // Where do we go from here?
    (resolved | rejected) -> // Ah, yes

  // And now we're all finished
  done
`
Finally, here's a more full example:

var dragDropChart = `
  idle ->
    drag-detect ->
      (dragging | clicked)

  // Just a click, bail-out!
  clicked -> idle

  // Drag detected!
  dragging ->
    drag-wait -> dragged -> drag-wait

  // Drag finished...
  (drag-wait | dragged) ->
    (drag-done | drag-cancel) ->
      idle
`

tags.description: A function that can change the state when called.

tags.title: example
tags.description:
var machine = Statebot('popup-menu', {
  chart: `
    idle -> menu-opened ->
      (item-clicked | idle)

    item-clicked -> idle
  `,
  startIn: 'menu-opened'
})

button.onclick = machine.Enter('item-clicked')
machine.currentState()
// "menu-opened"

button.onclick()
machine.currentState()
// "item-clicked"

examples.description:
var machine = Statebot('popup-menu', {
  chart: `
    idle -> menu-opened ->
      (item-clicked | idle)

    item-clicked -> idle
  `,
  startIn: 'menu-opened'
})

button.onclick = machine.Enter('item-clicked')
machine.currentState()
// "menu-opened"

button.onclick()
machine.currentState()
// "item-clicked"

A function that can change the state when called.

Returns all states the machine has been in so far, up to a limit set
by

tags.title: memberof
tags.description: statebotFsm

tags.title: returns
tags.description: A copy of the state-history.

tags.title: example
tags.description:
var machine = Statebot('downloader', {
  chart: `
    loading -> (failure | success)
      failure -> loading
      success -> done
  `,
  historyLimit: 4
})

machine.enter('failure')
machine.enter('loading')
machine.enter('success')
machine.enter('done')
machine.history()
// ["failure", "loading", "success", "done"]

examples.description:
var machine = Statebot('downloader', {
  chart: `
    loading -> (failure | success)
      failure -> loading
      success -> done
  `,
  historyLimit: 4
})

machine.enter('failure')
machine.enter('loading')
machine.enter('success')
machine.enter('done')
machine.history()
// ["failure", "loading", "success", "done"]

Returns the state-machine to its starting-state and clears the
state-history.

All listeners will still be attached, but no events or
transitions will be fired. The pause-state will be maintained.

tags.title: memberof
tags.description: statebotFsm

tags.title: example
tags.description:
var machine = Statebot('carousel', {
  chart: `
    page-1 ->
    page-2 ->
    page-3 ->
    page-4 -> page-1
  `
})

machine.enter('page-2')
machine.reset()
machine.currentState()
// "page-1"

examples.description:
var machine = Statebot('carousel', {
  chart: `
    page-1 ->
    page-2 ->
    page-3 ->
    page-4 -> page-1
  `
})

machine.enter('page-2')
machine.reset()
machine.currentState()
// "page-1"

tags.description: Describe the success-condition for this assertion.

tags.description: Wait for the machine to be in this state before assertion begins.

tags.description: Run this function just before starting the assertion.

tags.title: property
tags.description:
If we hit an unexpected state during assertion, this is a "deviation".
 It might be that the FSM will come back to the expected state again
 after a certain number of these. For example, if your FSM has a
 "retry" route configured, this number can account for it.
tags.name: permittedDeviations

tags.title: property
tags.description: Permitted length of time for the entire assertion, in milliseconds.
tags.name: timeoutInMs

tags.title: property
tags.description:
Normally we want logs for assertions, right? Well, you can tune
 them just like you can with {@link #statebotoptions|statebotOptions}.
tags.name: logLevel

after a certain number of these. For example, if your FSM has a
"retry" route configured, this number can account for it.
